item.content:encoded:
Click to read the briefing

The 20th Century composer Igor Stravinsky (1882-1971), who himself was a connoisseur of music from previous periods, gave this quote as part of a series of lectures he gave at Harvard University in 1939. Drawing on your own thoughts and experience, and clearly referring to the four points below as well as developing ideas of your own, write 500 words discussing Stravinsky’s phrase from the point of view of rules in music. Try to explore your ideas as far as you can – especially the ones that are particularly important to you.

  • Did you find strategies to cope with the rules outlined in this chapter?
  • What steps could you take to learn writing 16th Century counterpoint?
  • What qualities do you think the strictness of 16th Century compositional technique brings to the music?
  • Discuss the value of rules in composing and performing music.

Reflection

Upon reading Stravinsky’s quote, I understood it quite intuitively. Due to my advertising background, most of the creative challenges I faced had constraints, so this subject is dear to me. In my experience, it was the “open challenges,” those without boundaries or limitations, that were the hardest to overcome.

Considering I could explore the theme more, the 500-word limit felt a bit short to me. There is a lot to discuss about rules’ effectiveness, human bodies and instruments as extrinsic limitations, rules’ roles in AI music composition, and if there is a right amount of restriction that promotes creativity. Nevertheless, I realized that a 500-word essay about constraints needs a constraint, so I summarized my main points.

Throughout this essay, the word “constraint” can take on many forms, such as “rule”, “limit”, or “boundary”. In most cases, however, the meaning remains the same. A set of extrinsic and intrinsic restraints that an artist is confronted with when using a creative medium.

Essay

In this quote, apart from playing with paradoxical word use, Stravinsky was saying that all creativity revolves around solving problems (Harnad et al., 2008). I believe he was arguing that for creativity to reach its full potential, there must be some tension that calls for resolution. Many artists, including Mozart (Blanning, 2016), Frank Gehry (Hereld, 2013), and John Stweart (NPR, 2015), have defended the same position. Constraints and problems are essential for artists so that they can find solutions that will produce knowledge.

What artists develop within these limitations and rules depends on their goals and skills. Beethoven broke them (Page, 2019). Gesualdo bent them (Ross, 2011). John Cage created new ones (Savenko, 2021). However, one thing unites them all. Each of them mastered the rules before creating beyond them.

Even when one considers musical genres in addition to musicians, it becomes apparent that they too need rules. New musical genres are created when “socially accepted rules” are set over the traditional ones (Fabbri, 1980). There is always a cycle: established rules are mastered; then they are questioned; then new rules are developed.

This was evident when monophonic masses were replaced by polyphonic ones. It was a breaking of the rules of a single melodic line that led to the establishment of new rules by the church at the Trent Council and mastered by Palestrina (Monson, 2002). During the 16th Century, these formal rules led to a strictness in compositional technique, which ultimately led to not only a controlled, contemplative, and accessible sound, but also one that was predictable and standardized. By no means am I arguing that the rules were demeaning the music, but they were purely a necessity for the Church to standardize music during the Renaissance (Mock, 2017), which was a time of profound creative and cultural shifts.

To assist composers in learning these contrapuntal compositional techniques of the 16th Century, Johann-Joseph Fux authored in 1725 the Gradus ad Parnassum, during a time when composers refused “to be bound by any rules or principles” (Fux et al., 1971). They are known as species counterpoint and have been a part of the learning of Mozart, Beethoven and Haydn (Norman, nd) and my own learning as well.

To learn and implement these rules, I found it most helpful to understand the “why” behind them. For example, understanding why consecutive fifths and octaves, and unison passages can render the music too dull and boring makes it easier to remember than simply telling me “do not use successive fifths and octaves, or unison passages”. As well as this, I relied on the progressive learning method, where one learns by doing (Kennedy, 2019). This made learning easier by increasing the difficulty one step at a time and letting my mind become accustomed to the rules as I progressed.

Ultimately, the rules and constraints proved to be beneficial to me, as they helped me learn different harmonization and melodic concepts, and proved effective since I was able to compose much faster than I would without them. They also proved useful in helping me become more creative as I learned to solve some musical problems and maybe even come up with new ones in the future.

First Species

Using the tips from the First Species, I created a melodic line that was always consonant and moved mostly in contrary motion.

Second Species

My greatest struggle came in bars 3 and 4, where I was trying to connect the melody with the given D in bar 4. Keeping with the instructions to make leaps inside the bar, I decided to leap from B to E in bar 3.

Third Species

Due to the pre-given patterns in bar 4 (nota cambiata pattern) and bar 6 (double neighbour pattern) in the third species, I started this species backwards in bar 6. Even with the given patterns, I tried to maintain a fluid melodic line with no big leaps, and always respected the previous species’ guidelines.

Fourth Species

Since the suspension must be resolved downwards and in consonance with the upbeat, I found this one to be the easiest species. 

Fifth Species

As compared to the previous species, the fifth one took me a lot lI wasn’t sure how the bass and alto should harmonize with the tenor while imitating each other. Jacob Gran’s video helped me realize we should make the three-voice counterpoint as harmonically complete as possible. Thus, for example, in bar 3, the bass is supposed to imitate the tenor by going from D to F, but that would be dissonant. The right choice is E since it makes a C major triad.
